I like this idea a lot. My opinions on the about the points above:

1. This sounds good to me :+1:

2. If users say they want to enforce code style, do we then offer them the choice of picking from a list of popular styleguide configs?

3. I like the idea of asking about what framework people are using, as that's a much more beginner-friendly question (and I think the `--init` option should really optimize for lowering the barrier for entry for people new to ESLint).

*Edit:* I missed the autoconfig option. I'd be fine with removing this, especially now that our autofixers are in a pretty good place and tools like Prettier exist.

1. That seems like a good default selection :+1:
2. Your proposal sounds much more in line with how I perceive people actually want to approach ESLint. Especially approaching it the first time, immediately asking someone what style guide they want to use can be overwhelming. To @kaicataldoâ€™s point, if theyâ€™ve decided they want to check style, _then_ we could present an option for popular style guides. (Potentially out of scope, but throwing it out there: do we want to make automatically configuring the Prettier integration one of the options? It didnâ€™t exist when `--init` was originally created.)
3. I like this for the same reason I like (2) - it asks people what they want to do, not how they intend to do it.

I could argue either way about removing autoconfig. I wish we had some way of knowing how much itâ€™s used. Is its presence a maintenance burden, or does it prevent some other feature? If so, letâ€™s get rid of it.

Oh yes, sorry I wasnâ€™t clear: if they say they want to enforce Styles, then
Iâ€™d present the same options that we have now.

I wouldnâ€™t want to deal with Prettier at this point. I think trying to
integrate another tool into this process is fraught with peril and
maintenance headaches.

Regarding autoconfig, I just donâ€™t see a lot of mention of it online. It
seems that people are generally happy to choose an already existing style
guide. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s hurting us right now, but figured Iâ€™d bring it up
for discussion.

FWIW I used autoconfig on my most recent global install of eslint. Even though I gave it my files, it still turned on a bunch of style rules that violate how my code was written.

@getify That seems like it shouldn't be happening. Would you mind creating a new issue for it?

I'm not extremely attached to autoconfig (it could also probably be its own tool), but I don't think it has been a significant maintenance burden recently, so I'd lean against removing it since it seems like it could be convenient for users.

**TSC Summary:** This proposal seeks to update the `--init` questions to eliminate asking for `ecmaVersion` (assume latest, which is 2018 now), ask if you're using Vue/React, and ask if you want ESLint to enforce styles. An optional piece of this is to remove autoconfig as an option, but that is not a blocker to the rest of this proposal.

**TSC Question:** Shall we accept this proposal? Should autoconfig be removed as part of it or no?

The autoconfig portion of #11105 is being moved into this new issue after discussion in today's TSC meeting. The rest of this description was originally written by @nzakas in #11105:

<!--
    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://js.foundation/community/code-of-conduct).

    This template is for requesting a change that is not a bug fix, rule change, or new rule. If you are here for another reason, please see below:

    1. To report a bug: https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/reporting-bugs
    2. To request a rule change: https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/rule-changes
    3. To propose a new rule: https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/new-rules
    4. If you have any questions, please stop by our chatroom: https://gitter.im/eslint/eslint

    Note that leaving sections blank will make it difficult for us to troubleshoot and we may have to close the issue.
-->

**The problem you want to solve.**

The `--init` behavior has remained pretty consistent since it was first launched. At that point, we didn't know what options people wanted and the number of rules was very small. It seems like the current questions don't make sense for how ESLint is used today. For example, forcing people to pick a style guide doesn't make sense for everyone and sends a message that ESLint is used primarily for styling. I'd like to update the behavior of `--init` to better reflect current users expectations and usage.

**Your take on the correct solution to problem.**

**Remove autoconfig option.** I'm not sure how people feel about this, but I'm skeptical that this option is used all that much thanks to the popularity of shareable configs. I'm in favor of removing it if others agree but have no problem leaving it in if people feel it's still helpful. 

**Are you willing to submit a pull request to implement this change?**

Yes.

body: Based on today's TSC meeting, we decided to accept the changes to the questions asked by `--init`, and I've move discussion about removing autoconfig into #11235.

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**

Rearranged the questions that are asked using `--init`. We now assume the latest version of ECMAScript is desired.

Also, there was a bug where if you chose a style guide the resulting config would have nothing but the resulting style guide. I fixed that.

The majority of the work was in rearranging the order of the questions. That part is pretty hard to follow but I did my best to clean it up for this round of changes. If we decide to remove autoconfig, I'd do some deeper cleaning.

In addition to the unit tests, I manually tested that each path through the questionnaire works locally.

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**

Anything that I missed?
